data.title: Castellum rises after announcing $66.2M Navy contract to SSI subsidiary
data.description:
• Castellum (CTM) surged over 18% on Friday after it announced that its subsidiary Specialty Systems ((SSI)) has been awarded a $66.2 million full and open, five year Navy contract.
  • SSI will provide services supporting the execution of logistics, engineering, and cyber work products for aircraft carriers and air-capable ships and associated support systems.
  • The company said the contract is to support the Naval Air Warfare Center Aircraft Division ((NAWCAD)) Lakehurst ((LKE)) Mission Operations & Integration ((MO&I)) Department. 
  • CTM stock was trading at $1.22 in the morning on Friday.
  • Source: Press Release

data.title: Federal Realty Investment Q3 earnings top consensus; raises lower end of guidance
data.description:
Federal Realty Trust (FRT) stock gained 2.2% in Friday morning trading after the retail REIT raised the lower end of its full-year FFO guidance range as Q3 earnings and revenue benefited from strong leasing volume and rent spreads.

The REIT now expects full-year FFO per share to be $7.05-$ 7.11, excluding $0.15 of new market tax credit transaction income, (midpoint $7.08 vs. $7.06 consensus, excluding NMTC income) vs. its previous guidance of $7.01-$7.11.

Q3 FFO per share of $1.77, topping the average analyst estimate of $1.76, rose from $1.76 in Q2 and $1.77 in last year’s Q3.

Q3 total revenue of $322.3M, beating the $315.3M consensus, increased from $302.5M in the prior quarter and $303.6M in the year-ago period.

Operating expenses of $211.6M climbed from $199.5M in Q2 and $197.8M in Q3 2024.

"Record leasing volume and some of the strongest rent spreads in our history underscore the demand for our properties and the power of our platform," said CEO Donald C. Wood. "We're driving NOI growth and maintaining sharp focus on disciplined capital allocation that drives compounding growth over time."

Federal Realty (FRT) generated comparable property operating income growth of 4.4%, excluding lease termination fees and prior period rents collected, during the quarter vs. 4.9% growth in Q2.

Comparable portfolio occupancy of 94.0% improved 40 basis points from the prior quarter and 20 bps from a year ago.

Its leased rate of 95.7% at the end of Q3 improved 10 bps from the end of Q2 and declined 10 bps from the end of Q3 2024. 

During the quarter, Federal Realty signed 132 leases totaling 774,890 square feet of retail space. On a comparable space basis, it signed 123 leases for 727,029 square feet at an average rent of $35.71 per square foot, compared with $27.85 under prior leases, representing a 28% increase on a cash basis, and a 43% increase on a straight-line basis.

data.title: Strategy stock climbs as firm explores global bitcoin-backed credit expansion
data.description:
Strategy (MSTR) shares gained 7.2% in Friday late morning trading after a day after the bitcoin (BTC-USD) treasury firm posted a second straight quarter of profits, thanks in part to unrealized bitcoin gains and solid growth in its smaller software business.

The rally also comes after management said it's looking to expand its capital raising efforts globally, given the notion that bitcoin-backed credit instruments are still in their early phase of adoption. This was "the real news," noted Benchmark analyst Mark Palmer, who ranks MSTR a Buy.

"I want MSTR to stand for 'monster,'" Michael Saylor said during his company's post-earnings call, signaling a ramp-up in bitcoin (BTC-USD) buying fueled by digital credit. "We want to create a monster company. We want to create the digital credit instruments that are two to four times better than everything in the $300T market."

During the three-month period ended Sept. 30, 2025, Strategy (MSTR) received net proceeds totaling $5.1B, and additional net proceeds of ~$89.5M in the Oct. 1-26 period, from its common stock at-the-market program, as well as its (STRK) ATM program, (STRF) ATM program, (STRD) ATM program, and the initial public offering of (STRC) stock.

Saylor said that Strategy's (MSTR) market-adjusted net asset value (mNAV) has fallen to 1.25 over the past few quarters -- its lowest mark since early last year. He attributed the decline to several developments, from a more mature bitcoin (BTC-USD) market with lower volatility to the growing role of derivatives, which further stabilizes price swings.

Despite the compression, Saylor said he remains confident that digital credit growth, driven by preferred equity instruments, will eventually push the company's mNAV higher.

data.title: Proto Labs expects up to 6% Q4 revenue growth as U.S. CNC machining momentum drives record results
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Proto Labs (PRLB) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Suresh Krishna, President and CEO, highlighted "record quarterly revenues and exceeded earnings expectations, highlighting the strength of our model and the power of focused execution." Krishna noted increased demand in U.S. CNC machining and sheet metal offerings, especially from aerospace, defense, and industrial machinery segments. He stated, "Our record revenue was led by increased demand in our U.S. CNC machining and sheet metal offerings, supported by strength across several key end markets."
  • Krishna described Proto Labs' expanding relationships with major customers, such as Amazon and Blue Origin, and emphasized the company's role supplying "mission-critical precision parts in innovative areas like drones, satellites and space exploration."
  • The CEO pointed to a "comprehensive strategic planning process to identify specific initiatives and projects to accelerate growth and improve our operations." He committed to sharing more details in 2026 but stressed near-term focus on "removing friction, expanding our offerings and deepening customer relationships."
  • Krishna announced an expansion of CNC machining capacity, citing "strong demand" and recent launches of advanced CNC machining capabilities, now available through Proto Labs' e-commerce platform.
  • The company appointed Marc Kermisch as Chief Technology and AI Officer, tasked with leading "digital transformation and AI strategy" and further embedding AI and automation in operations.
  • Dan Schumacher, CFO, stated, "Third quarter revenue was a company record $135.4 million, up 7.8% year-over-year or 6.8% in constant currencies. Revenue fulfilled through Proto Labs Network was $30.1 million, up 16.2% in constant currencies."

Outlook

  • The company forecasts fourth quarter revenue between $125 million and $133 million, which at the midpoint implies 6% revenue growth year-over-year.
  • Schumacher said, "We expect foreign currency to have a $1.5 million favorable impact on revenue compared to the fourth quarter of 2024."
  • Fourth quarter non-GAAP earnings per share are projected between $0.30 and $0.38.
  • Management stated, "We anticipate non-GAAP add-backs in the fourth quarter to include stock-based compensation expense of approximately $3.9 million and amortization expense of $900,000. We currently estimate a non-GAAP effective tax rate between 23% and 24% in the fourth quarter."

Financial Results

  • Revenue reached a record $135.4 million for Q3, up 7.8% year-over-year.
  • Revenue fulfilled through Proto Labs Network was $30.1 million.
  • CNC machining revenue grew 18.2% year-over-year, with U.S. CNC machining revenue up 24%.
  • Injection molding grew 2% year-over-year, while 3D printing revenue declined 6.3% and sheet metal grew 13.9%.
  • Non-GAAP gross margin was 45.9%, up 110 basis points sequentially.
  • Non-GAAP operating expenses were $48.6 million or 35.9% of revenue.
  • Third quarter adjusted EBITDA was $21.1 million or 15.6% of revenue.
  • Non-GAAP earnings per share were $0.47, up $0.06 sequentially.
  • Cash from operations for the quarter was $29.1 million, with $138.4 million in cash and investments and no debt at quarter end.
  • $12.8 million was returned to shareholders via share repurchases.

Q&A

  • Greg Palm, Craig-Hallum: Asked about Proto Labs' growth opportunity and long-term growth rate. Krishna responded, "We are very focused on driving growth. Our last two quarters would indicate that. We've been above 7% two quarters in a row." He added that new strategic initiatives will be shared in 2026 and noted, "The confidence we have in future growth is things we are doing right now are resonating very strongly with our customers."
  • Palm: Asked about company-specific growth initiatives. Krishna detailed the advanced machining capabilities developed in response to customer feedback and noted growth "across several industries," not just aerospace and defense, emphasizing the company's diverse customer base.
  • Palm: Questioned CapEx requirements for CNC expansion. Schumacher: "We're fine from a facility perspective. This is just continuing to add mills... we can expand very quickly just by adding mills to the facility."
  • Troy Jensen, Cantor Fitzgerald: Questioned declining unique developer numbers. Krishna acknowledged focus on growing share of wallet and stated, "We are absolutely focused on growing our customer base."
  • Jensen: Asked about cross-selling. Schumacher explained, "Of those customers, that are in the trailing 12 months, have ordered from both the network and the factory... that's up 35% year-over-year."
  • Brian Drab, William Blair: Asked about automation in advanced CNC machining. Krishna explained the process is now a "digital thread" via the e-commerce platform, removing manual intervention.
  • Drab: Questioned medium-term prospects for injection molding. Krishna noted reduced prototyping activity is driving softness but said, "we'll redouble our efforts for growth in all our service lines."
  • James Ricchiuti, Needham: Asked about gross margin performance and network margins. Schumacher responded, "Network gross margins were around 33% in the quarter... we were successfully able to implement changes both to our pricing and our sourcing algorithms so that in the third quarter, even though tariff costs were still up, we were able to improve our margins quarter-over-quarter in the network."
  • Ricchiuti: Asked about drivers of revenue per customer. Krishna said, "We are seeing improvements from new and existing customers... share of wallet increase across different industries."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for details on growth sustainability, customer base expansion, and automation, showing a neutral to slightly positive tone, with appreciation for results but probing on future growth and execution.
  • Management maintained a confident and optimistic tone, particularly in prepared remarks. Krishna repeatedly referenced strong momentum and confidence: "I could not be more confident in Proto Labs' ability to execute with speed, discipline and innovation."
  • Compared to Q2, management's tone was more assertive and forward-looking, while analysts' tone remained focused on fundamentals, demonstrating cautious optimism.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q3 guidance and commentary project a 6% year-over-year revenue growth for Q4, compared to similar guidance in Q2 for Q3. Management's confidence has increased, with more emphasis on execution and operational momentum.
  • Revenue per customer improved nearly 15% year-over-year in Q3 versus an 11% increase in Q2. Customers utilizing both factory and network fulfillment grew 35% in Q3 compared to 44% in Q2.
  • U.S. CNC machining growth remained a highlight, though overall European revenue continued to contract.
  • Management's tone in Q3 is more focused on strategic execution and innovation, while Q2 focused on foundational strengths and early impressions from the new CEO.
  • Analysts’ focus shifted slightly from margin pressures and tariffs in Q2 to growth drivers and automation in Q3.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management acknowledged ongoing contraction in European manufacturing activity and continued weak demand in 3D printing, particularly in Europe.
  • Tariff uncertainty and implementation challenges persist, though management reported improved margins through pricing and sourcing adjustments.
  • Analysts questioned sustainability of customer growth and share of wallet expansion, as well as the flat performance of the injection molding business.
  • Management highlighted efforts to expand CNC capacity and invest in technology to mitigate these risks.

Final Takeaway

Proto Labs delivered record third quarter revenue and earnings, driven by robust demand in U.S. CNC machining and ongoing operational improvements. Management signaled ongoing momentum heading into year-end with a Q4 revenue outlook that implies 6% year-over-year growth and continued focus on automation, digital transformation, and customer expansion initiatives. Share of wallet gains among large customers, expanded advanced machining capabilities, and a strengthened leadership team position the company for further growth, while management remains attentive to challenges in Europe and certain service lines.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Lumen targets $1.1B in incremental revenue by 2028 through digital and PCF growth as AI demand accelerates
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Lumen Technologies (LUMN) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Kathleen Johnson, President, CEO & Director, opened the call by highlighting "strong financial results with revenue, EBITDA and free cash flow all coming in ahead of Street consensus" and announced continued progress in business transformation, including "a successful phase 1 implementation of our new ERP system, delivering more than $250 million in run rate cost takeout through the end of Q3, on track for $350 million this year." Johnson emphasized significant debt refinancing actions totaling $2.4 billion and progress on the consumer fiber-to-the-home sale to AT&T.
  • Johnson detailed a strategic pivot toward revenue growth, revealing "we signed an additional $1-plus billion in private connectivity fabric deals since our last update, bringing the total PCF deal value to over $10 billion." She underscored scaling of NaaS, now serving more than 1,500 enterprise customers, and the launch of Internet on-demand off-net, which she described as giving "nearly 100x greater market reach to accelerate digital service sales and revenue growth."
  • Johnson stated, "our growing revenue base now comprises 50% of North American enterprise revenue, up from 35.5% just 3 years ago," and positioned Lumen as uniquely situated to meet AI-driven networking needs, referencing five essential network capabilities as foundational to Lumen’s strategy.
  • Johnson projected, "the $10 billion of business in hand plus the existing O&M run rate business for PCF, we expect will yield a recurring revenue stream ranging between $400 million and $500 million by the time we exit 2028," and forecasted digital initiatives to contribute "somewhere between $500 million and $600 million of incremental revenue run rate exiting 2028."
  • A strategic partnership with Palantir was announced, expanding the connected ecosystem alongside collaborations with Microsoft, Google, AWS, Digital Realty, QTS, Databricks, and others.
  • Christopher Stansbury, Executive VP & CFO, stated, "Financially, revenue, adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow results were better than expected. Our total business grow revenue was up 7.7% year-over-year and our total business revenue was only down 3.2% year-over-year, well ahead of the competition."
  • Stansbury highlighted, "the third quarter debt refinancing term loan repricing and debt reduction actions further reduces annual interest expense by approximately $135 million. Year-to-date, we reduced annual interest expense by approximately $235 million through proactive balance sheet management."

Outlook

  • Stansbury reiterated, "we expect fourth quarter revenue to be negatively impacted by additional declines in public sector Harvest revenue as that revenue returns to more normalized levels, similar to the third quarter of 2024."
  • "We reiterate that we expect to come in near the high end of our $3.2 billion to $3.4 billion guidance range despite the previously announced $46 million RDOF giveback in the second quarter."
  • Lumen maintains its 2025 CapEx guidance at $4.1 billion to $4.3 billion, expecting to be at the low end of that range, and its full year free cash flow guidance at $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion, which includes an anticipated $400 million tax refund.
  • Management stated, "we remain confident that we will achieve adjusted EBITDA stability over the next few quarters and see an inflection to growth in 2026 driven mainly by continued M&A savings as well as improving revenue declines."

Financial Results

  • Stansbury reported, "Total reported revenue declined 4.2% to $3.087 billion. Business segment revenue declined 3.2% to $2.456 billion. Mass Market segment revenue declined 7.7% to $631 million. Adjusted EBITDA was $787 million with a 25.5% margin and free cash flow was $1.7 billion."
  • North American enterprise grow revenue increased 10.5% year-over-year, driven by strength in dark fiber and IP. Grow now represents half of North American enterprise revenue.
  • Mass markets fiber broadband revenue increased 18.4% year-over-year; Lumen added approximately 122,000 fiber-enabled homes and 39,000 Quantum Fiber customers during the quarter.
  • Special items impacting adjusted EBITDA totaled $216 million, including severance, transaction and separation costs, and modernization initiatives. Capital expenditures were approximately $1 billion in Q3.

Q&A

  • Michael Rollins, Citigroup: Asked about PCF deal margins and the sustainability of Grow revenue growth. Johnson responded, "the composition of that portfolio of bookings is equivalent in margins to the prior tranches... We're only going to do the business that's deeply accretive," and Stansbury noted that "PCF is certainly contributing, but it's not driving the total growth."
  • Sebastiano Petti, JPMorgan: Inquired about EBITDA bridge and balance sheet strength. Stansbury explained, "business mix continues to improve, which means the rate of decline continues to improve... the big driver... is the modernization and simplification efforts."
  • Frank Louthan, Raymond James: Probed revenue impacts from ecosystem partnerships. Johnson said, "the connected ecosystem is a part of the storyboard of how we have confidence in getting to $500 million to $600 million incremental revenue exiting '28."
  • Gregory Williams, TD Cowen: Asked about equity issuance and the AI phase timeline. Johnson described the AI build as a "multi-decade journey... phase 1 will overlap with phase 2," while Stansbury discussed stock valuation and capital allocation.
  • Eric Luebchow, Wells Fargo: Questioned investment requirements for digital growth. Johnson confirmed, "the investments required to build the digital platform are definitely significant. They're already contemplated in all of our plans."
  • Nicholas Del Deo, MoffettNathanson: Sought clarification on NaaS sales strategy and PCF deal economics. Johnson stated, "we will demote the old-school analog version of that service and prioritize it in terms of engineering resources, marketing resource, sales resource and operations resource."
  • Michael Funk, BofA: Asked about Lumen's departure from traditional telecom models. Stansbury explained, "traditional telecom was a battlefield of every single services requiring its own infrastructure layer... That's not what we're doing... we're monetizing what is the most modern, the most high capacity, the fastest network by adding a digital layer in an ecosystem layer."
  • Jonathan Atkin, RBC: Explored off-net NaaS capabilities and M&A. Johnson described the vision for off-net NaaS and upcoming Project Berkeley, emphasizing expanded market reach and integration.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for specifics on digital revenue growth, margin sustainability, and the timeline for AI-driven infrastructure, with a generally neutral to slightly positive tone and some skepticism on execution and timing.
  • Management maintained a confident and upbeat tone in both prepared remarks and Q&A, frequently referencing discipline, innovation, and market leadership, and using phrases like "we believe our investment thesis and strategy are showing tangible results."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone showed increased confidence, especially regarding digital growth and debt profile improvements, while analysts remained probing but acknowledged progress on transformation targets.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter saw Lumen announce an additional $1 billion in PCF deals (now totaling over $10 billion), compared to $500 million added in the previous quarter. Guidance for incremental digital and PCF revenue exiting 2028 was newly quantified at $900 million to $1.1 billion.
  • Grow revenue growth accelerated to 10.5% year-over-year from 8.5% previously, with Grow now comprising 50% of North American enterprise revenue (up from over 48%).
  • Management reiterated guidance and cost reduction targets, and highlighted further balance sheet strengthening, while evolving the narrative toward scaling digital ecosystem partnerships and launching new digital products.
  • Analysts continued to focus on margin durability, digital adoption, and clarity on growth inflection, but the shift in discussion centered increasingly on digital platform expansion and AI market opportunity.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management noted anticipated declines in public sector Harvest revenue and ongoing legacy telecom revenue pressure.
  • Johnson acknowledged the complexity and cost of new build PCF projects and emphasized maintaining deal discipline.
  • Stansbury cautioned that "adjusted EBITDA margins were disproportionately impacted by anticipated declines in public sector Harvest revenue in the third quarter."
  • The receipt of a $400 million tax refund could be delayed by a prolonged government shutdown.
  • Analysts raised questions around the timing and magnitude of digital revenue realization, investment requirements, and execution on strategic partnerships.

Final Takeaway

Lumen Technologies reported strong Q3 financial results, accelerated its pivot to revenue growth with over $1 billion in new PCF deals, and projected $900 million to $1.1 billion in incremental digital and PCF revenue by 2028. Management underscored balance sheet improvements and a disciplined approach to digital transformation, including major ecosystem partnerships and scalable NaaS adoption. While legacy revenue declines and sector normalization remain challenges, Lumen emphasized confidence in its growth trajectory, driven by ongoing innovation, operational execution, and a clear strategic focus on enabling AI-driven networking infrastructure.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: The Bancorp targets $7 EPS run rate by Q4 2026 amid fintech expansion and platform restructuring
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: The Bancorp, Inc. (TBBK) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Damian Kozlowski, CEO, reported that "in the third quarter, The Bancorp earned $1.18 earnings per share on revenue growth of 7%, excluding consumer fintech loan credit enhancement income and expense growth of 6%." EPS grew 13% year-over-year, while fintech GDV continued to grow above trend at 16%. He highlighted revenue growth in the quarter, including both fee and related interest income, as 23%.
  • Kozlowski outlined progress in three main fintech initiatives: credit sponsorship balances ended at 785, up 15% from the second quarter and 180% year-over-year; the embedded finance platform is set for launch next year; and the Cash App program is on track with revenue expected in the first quarter of 2026. He stated, "All 3 initiatives should have an increasingly positive effect on our financials as we move forward through '26 and into 2027."
  • The company reduced criticized REBL assets from $216 million to $185 million, a 14% quarter-over-quarter decline, and expects more progress in the fourth quarter.
  • Under Project 7, Kozlowski announced a restructuring of the institutional banking business in Q4 2025, reducing headcount by 30 and decreasing run rate expenses by approximately $8 million, with a $1.3 million restructuring charge expected in Q4.
  • Kozlowski disclosed that guidance for 2025 is being lowered to $5.10 per share, primarily due to lower projected balances in traditional lending and increased credit provision for leasing. Preliminary guidance for 2027 is introduced at $8.25 earnings per share.
  • Martin Egan, Interim CFO, stated, "Excluding consumer fintech loan credit enhancement income, noninterest income for the third quarter of 2025 was $40.6 million, which was 27% higher than the third quarter of 2024. Total fintech fees accounted for most of that increase."
  • Egan also reported a $2.3 million settlement included in other income and provision for credit losses on nonconsumer fintech loans of $5.8 million for the quarter, with $4.8 million related to the leasing portfolio.

Outlook

  • Kozlowski reported that "we are lowering guidance to $5.10-ish a share for '25, primarily due to lower projected balances on our traditional lending businesses and an increased credit provision for leasing due to losses on the disposition of previously identified credits in trucking."
  • The company is not providing specific guidance for 2026 other than targeting a minimum $7 earnings per share run rate by the end of 2026.
  • Preliminary guidance for 2027 is set at $8.25 earnings per share.
  • Kozlowski said, "EPS gains are subject to uncertainty, particularly as it relates to the development implementation time lines in fintech and our stock price for buybacks."

Financial Results

  • Fintech fees for the quarter increased, with prepaid, debit card, ACH and other payment fees reaching $30.6 million, a 10% increase year-over-year, and consumer credit fintech fees rising $2.9 million to $4.5 million.
  • Provision for credit losses on nonconsumer fintech loans totaled $5.8 million, with $4.8 million related to leasing. Net charge-offs in leasing were $2.8 million, primarily from the trucking industry.
  • Average fintech solutions deposits grew 10% to $7.3 billion from $6.6 billion a year ago.
  • Noninterest expense for the quarter was $56.4 million, up 6% from the prior year, including a 10% increase in salaries and benefits.

Q&A

  • Timothy Switzer, KBW, asked for an update on the Cash App program timeline. Kozlowski replied, "it's on track and revenue is expected in Q1. We're not sure exactly the ramp-up schedule because it's really dependent on time lines at Block at Cash App."
  • Switzer inquired about the $27 million REBL loan sale. Kozlowski responded, "that $27 million is expected to close in the next 5 days."
  • Switzer questioned the activity in closing new loan sales. Kozlowski noted, "we've just been working with the borrowers, some in deferrals, right? ... The market has improved generally for these assets."
  • Switzer asked about lower deposits. Kozlowski explained, "There's a big seasonality part of it. ... We have plenty of deposits. The question is how do we manage it through the cycle so that we don't have these big ups and downs."
  • Joseph Yanchunis, Raymond James, sought details on share repurchases and guidance. Kozlowski said guidance includes buybacks and, "At that point, it will be $300-plus million of net income."
  • Yanchunis also asked about fintech fees' sequential decline. Kozlowski replied, "there's a lot of volatility. There's incentive fees. There's a whole bunch of things in there, and there's seasonality in there, too... but then it starts ramping up again."
  • Arif Gangat asked about REBL loan delinquency. Egan responded, "Some of that will be resolved in that $102 million that's under contract."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed for clarity on new program timelines, loan sales, deposit management, and share repurchase assumptions, showing a neutral to slightly cautious tone.
  • Management maintained confidence in fintech initiatives and guidance, though acknowledged uncertainties, as Kozlowski stated, "EPS gains are subject to uncertainty." During Q&A, explanations were more detailed, indicating thoroughness but also caution given the moving parts.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone shifted from more assertive to slightly more measured, reflecting the lower guidance and ongoing restructuring.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance was lowered from $5.25 to $5.10 per share for 2025, with preliminary 2027 guidance newly introduced at $8.25 per share.
  • The three main fintech initiatives remain a focal point, but the platform restructuring and AI investment have become more prominent.
  • Analysts continued to focus on loan performance, fintech fee volatility, and deposit dynamics, similar to the previous quarter.
  • Management's confidence remains but is tempered by increased references to uncertainty and operational adjustments, versus a more upbeat tone in Q2.

Risks and Concerns

  • Increased provision for credit losses in leasing, particularly from trucking sector exposures.
  • Lower projected balances in traditional lending.
  • Ongoing volatility in fintech fee income and deposit balances.
  • Uncertainty around fintech implementation timelines and the impact of share buybacks is acknowledged by management.

Final Takeaway

The Bancorp is navigating a transition period, with management emphasizing progress in fintech initiatives, platform efficiency, and restructuring efforts. While guidance for 2025 has been adjusted downward, leadership remains focused on achieving a $7 earnings per share run rate by the end of 2026 and sees further growth into 2027, driven by new product launches, AI-enabled efficiencies, and continued capital return through share buybacks.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Silvercrest outlines path to record discretionary AUM through ongoing global investments
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Silvercrest Asset Management Group Inc. (SAMG) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Richard Hough, CEO, President & Chairman, reported that discretionary assets under management (AUM) increased $687 million during the third quarter, attributing the growth primarily to beneficial equity markets. New client account flows were highlighted, with $46.4 million added in organic new client accounts during the quarter and $564 million year-to-date through Q3. Hough stated, “Discretionary AUM now stands at $24.3 billion, which is a 3% sequential quarterly increase and an increase of 8% year-over-year.” He further noted, “Total AUM at the end of the third quarter did hit a new high for the firm at $37.6 billion.”

  • Hough emphasized, “Silvercrest has embarked on significant strategic investments to promote growth opportunities,” with a focus on intellectual capital and headcount, which has led to substantially lower earnings and adjusted EBITDA in the near-term.

  • He announced an ongoing $25 million buyback program, stating, “As of the end of the third quarter of 2025, we have repurchased approximately $16 million worth of shares.” He also referenced a dividend of $0.21 per share set to be paid in December and plans to distribute equity incentives to professionals in the near future.

  • CFO Scott Gerard reported, “Revenue for the quarter was $31.3 million and reported consolidated net income for the quarter was $1.1 million.” Gerard added, “Expenses for the quarter increased year-over-year by $4 million or 15.4%, primarily driven by increased compensation and benefits expense and general and administrative expenses.”

Outlook

  • Hough indicated that, “Assuming supportive markets and continued business development, we hope discretionary AUM will exceed all-time highs in the coming quarters.” He also described a plan to adjust nondiscretionary AUM reporting in 2026 to provide clearer business metrics.

  • Management expects the compensation ratio to remain elevated for the foreseeable future due to ongoing investments in personnel and global marketing.

  • The firm’s pipeline remains “robust, in particular with regards to our new global value equity strategy.” Hough highlighted, “We could see even some reasonable allocations in the fourth quarter or first quarter coming up here… which would obviously cover about 6 months.”

Financial Results

  • Gerard reported, “Revenue for the quarter increased $0.9 million or 2.9% year-over-year.” Compensation and benefits expense rose $3.1 million or 16.8% year-over-year, influenced by both merit-based increases and new hires, and an increase in the accrual for bonuses.

  • General and administrative expenses climbed $0.9 million or approximately 11.9% year-over-year, attributed to professional fees, occupancy, and recruiting costs.

  • Reported net income attributable to Class A shareholders for the quarter was $0.6 million or $0.07 per basic and diluted Class A share. Adjusted EBITDA was $4.5 million or 14.5% of revenue for the quarter. Adjusted net income was $2.4 million or $0.19 per adjusted basic and diluted earnings per share.

  • As of September 30, total assets stood at $157.6 million, with cash and cash equivalents at $36.1 million. No borrowings were reported, and total Class A stockholders’ equity was $58.9 million. The company repurchased $4.6 million worth of Class A shares during the quarter.

Q&A

  • Christopher Marinac, Janney Montgomery Scott: “Do we think about this as maybe an 18-, 24-month time frame? Or is it any way to kind of give visibility on that?” Hough responded that the bulk of investments have been recent and that, “you’re looking at a longer time horizon of 18 to 24 months,” but also expects shorter-term flows in the next 6 to 12 months from the global value equity strategy.

  • Marinac: “Are any of those [professional fees] temporary? Or will you have new professional fees to kind of cover in future periods?” Gerard replied, “Some of them are temporary, especially related to some of our global initiatives.”

  • Marinac: “Does the EBITDA margin get recast because it’s now going to be a different company with a different broader focus?” Hough answered, “You look out further and it gets back to where it was barring any other new investments.”

  • Sandy Mehta, Evaluate Research: “Can you just give us a little bit more color on what you’re seeing from a marketing perspective, the pipeline and what clients are saying or consultants are saying, what do you see out there on Global?” Hough described the pipeline as “very large” in international and global areas and noted, “our new centralized institutional marketing team and process has been highly engaged both with very significant sovereign pools of capital.”

  • Mehta: “Is most of the hiring done at this point of the senior people that you were hiring? Is that pace of incremental hires? Is that going to slow down?” Hough responded that most hiring for new equity strategy and institutional team is complete but further hires are expected for Europe, Asia, and domestically.

  • Mehta: “Where are you in terms of OCIO assets, currently?” Hough reported, “OCIO is almost $2.2 billion and has a very strong pipeline.”

  • Mehta: “Do you disclose what price you bought the stock?” Hough stated, “We don’t disclose it. I will say that it has been, from our thinking, a very, very favorable price.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts’ tone was generally neutral to slightly positive, focusing on the timing of returns from investments, the sustainability of professional fees, and the scale of hiring. Follow-up questions probed operating leverage and the trajectory of margins but did not express skepticism or overt concern.

  • Management maintained a confident tone, emphasizing the potential payoff from recent investments: “The potential is very large. And I’m quite confident that it is going to pay off and that we will be able to report meaningful progress soon.” Hough acknowledged the longer time horizon but was optimistic about near-term flows and future profitability.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, the current call reflected continued confidence in strategic initiatives, with management reiterating optimism about organic growth while acknowledging ongoing expense pressures and a longer investment payback period.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance continues to anticipate future record AUM levels, with management expecting discretionary AUM to exceed all-time highs in coming quarters, similar to the positive outlook last quarter.

  • Strategic focus remains on organic growth through international expansion, global value equity strategies, and headcount investments. The firm has moved from announcing new strategic hires to discussing the absorption and expected payoff of those investments.

  • Analysts’ questions shifted slightly from pipeline measurement and the pace of buybacks (Q2) to the timing of investment returns, margin recovery, and hiring trajectory (Q3), reflecting growing interest in when strategic investments will convert to earnings growth.

  • Key metrics reflect moderate sequential growth in AUM and revenue, but a noticeable decline in net income and EBITDA margin due to higher compensation and G&A expenses.

  • Management’s confidence level is steady, with ongoing emphasis on the size and quality of the pipeline and the robustness of international initiatives.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management highlighted elevated compensation and G&A expenses as ongoing challenges, tied to strategic hires and global expansion.

  • Analysts inquired about the possibility of continued high professional fees and whether the pace of hiring would slow, indicating concern about expense management relative to revenue realization.

  • Hough acknowledged that the timeline for investment returns is variable, with most hiring complete for current initiatives but further additions expected internationally and domestically.

Final Takeaway

Silvercrest Asset Management Group continues to invest heavily in its global and institutional capabilities, with discretionary AUM and total AUM both reaching new highs. Management is confident that recent investments in talent and international expansion will result in accelerated organic growth over the next 18 to 24 months, with a robust pipeline supporting future revenue. Expense pressures are expected to remain elevated in the near term, but the firm anticipates a return to higher margins as new business flows materialize. Investors should watch for updates on realized flows from global strategies and continued progress in international markets as key drivers for future earnings and AUM growth.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Brighthouse Financial surges 20% on report Aquarian nears $4B deal
data.description:
• Brighthouse Financial (BHF) jumped 20% after a report that Aquarian Holdings was in advanced talks to acquire the US life insurer.
  • Mubadala Capital-backed Aquarian Holding is expected to pay as much as $70 a share for Brighthouse, according to a Financial Times report  on Thursday. A deal could be announced as soon as this weekend.
  • Although talks have reached an advanced stage, no deal has yet been agreed to and talks could still fall apart, according to the report.
  • Brighthouse, Aquarian and Mubadala Capital declined to comment to the FT.

data.title: Roku stock turns positive and climbs +15% after Q3 profit beat
data.description:
Roku (ROKU) on Thursday reported a profit beat for the third quarter and provided a forecast that mostly matched Wall Street's expectations.

Shares fell more than 15% in immediate reaction to the report before paring losses. ROKU stock is up 15.6% in Friday's open market trading.

For the fourth quarter, Roku expects revenue to be $1.35B, ahead of the Bloomberg consensus estimate of $1.32B; gross profit of $575M, above the $571.9M estimate; and adjusted EBITDA of $395M vs. the consensus estimate of $376.2M.

The company, which makes streaming devices and owns a complimentary, ad-supported channel, said users streamed 36.5B hours in Q3, up 15% from last year, but below the estimate of 37.5B hours. 

Net income for the three months ended September 30 was $28.8M, compared with a loss of $9M for the same period last year.

On a per-share basis, the company earned 16 cents, beating the average analyst expectation of 8 cents a share.

Revenue rose 14% to $1.21B and was in line with the consensus estimate.

data.title: Black Diamond Group Limited raises dividend by 28.6% to CAD 0.045
data.description:
• Black Diamond Group Limited (BDI:CA) declares CAD 0.045/share quarterly dividend, 28.6% increase from prior dividend of CAD 0.035.
  • Payable Jan. 15; for shareholders of record Dec. 31; ex-div Dec. 31.
  • See BDI:CA Dividend Scorecard, Yield Chart, & Dividend Growth.
